P-??? asked for something that I think could be a game-changer — bulk share field mapping configurations with team in import wizard. Right now field mapping only works one at a time and their team processes 200+ items daily. They described this elaborate workaround involving CSV exports and reimports that takes over an hour. A native batch operation would probably save their team 5+ hours per week. I've heard variations of this from at least three other participants now.

After five sessions this week I'm noticing that the participants who struggle most with CSV export are actually our most engaged users. They're trying to share CSV export output with stakeholders in ways we didn't anticipate, pushing report builder beyond its designed scope. The less engaged users don't hit these issues because they stick to the happy path. This suggests our product is growing into a power-user tool but the UX hasn't kept up.

"My boss asks me for this every Friday and it takes me half the afternoon" — P-081 on access audit log workflow to use access audit log as part of their routine. user settings not optimized for recurring use.

Major pain point emerged around data refresh in home screen. P-119 tried to export data using data refresh and hit an error that just said 'Operation failed' with no details. They tried three more times with slightly different inputs before giving up and filing a support ticket. When I looked at the logs later, the issue was a file size limit that's nowhere in the UI. We're basically setting users up to fail and then giving them no way to understand why.

Marking this as a critical action — we need to share the user settings error state findings with engineering ASAP. P-101 and at least two others were completely blocked trying to improve SSO provisioning performance because SSO provisioning returned errors with no recovery path. I'm going to schedule a sync with the tech lead this week. These aren't edge cases, they're core workflow failures that are driving users to support.

"My team just exports it and does it in Excel because this is too slow" — on batch import in data ingestion area. Suggests the feature exists but is not performant or usable enough for real workflows.

One thing that keeps coming up is the disconnect between how we've organized main dashboard and how users think about their work. They don't think in terms of 'KPI cards' as a discrete thing — it's part of a larger job-to-be-done that spans multiple product areas. The fact that they have to share KPI cards output with stakeholders in one place and then go somewhere else to complete the workflow is the core friction, not any single UI element.
"The problem isn't this screen, it's that I have to come here at all" — participant on alerts section. Insight that the workflow itself is the issue, not just the escalation rules UI.

## Insight
- Pattern: New users complete understand data refresh results faster than experienced users in dashboard area
- Evidence: Onboarding cohort averaged 45s vs returning users at 2min+
- Root Cause: New users follow the guided flow; experienced users try shortcuts that don't exist for data refresh
- Implication: Adding keyboard shortcuts or quick-access panel would help power users

- Suggested Fix: Persist drill-down charts preferences per user across sessions

One thing that keeps coming up is the disconnect between how we've organized global search and how users think about their work. They don't think in terms of 'regex search' as a discrete thing — it's part of a larger job-to-be-done that spans multiple product areas. The fact that they have to integrate regex search into their process in one place and then go somewhere else to complete the workflow is the core friction, not any single UI element.
